awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Experimental and Computational Studies of Turbulence-Chemistry Interactions in Counter-Flow Flames as a Laboratory-Scale Benchmark for Practical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Collaborative Research:

1033204 
Gomez

1033246
Pope

Intellectual Merit: 

Developing an understanding of the complex interaction of fluid dynamics and chemical reactions in practical combustion devices is of fundamental importance for the development of combustion systems. Achieving this goal will assist in the development of the tools required for predictive modeling of such systems. For modeling to be reliable, systematic validation with an extensive experimental database is indispensable - a task for which practical, and inevitably complex, configurations are not as well suited as simple, well-defined laboratory flames. The PIs propose highly turbulent counterflow flames (TCFs) as a benchmark configuration for this type of systematic experimentation and modeling. They offer significant advantages, such as: flame stabilization without a pilot at high Reynolds numbers; compactness, with significant advantages for highly resolved computations; and versatility, with the ability to access a broad range of combustion regimes, especially those of industrial relevance. 

This research is collaboration between Yale and Cornell with further collaboration with Sandia National Labs. A series of experiments on TCFs, operating in both non-premixed and premixed modes, will be performed at Yale and at Sandia; simultaneously at Cornell, the same flames will be tackled computationally using the PDF and the LES-PDF methodologies. The principal contributions made by this research will be: (i) Providing qualitative understanding and quantitative data of TCFs in important but little-explored combustion regimes; (ii) Determining and demonstrating the capabilities of the PDF and LES-PDF methods to model accurately the TCFs in different regimes, and improving the sub-models as necessary. (iii) Providing the understanding and data necessary for TCFs to be a valuable benchmark for the development and testing of turbulent combustion models.

Broader Impact: 

Understanding turbulent combustion is important for power generation and propulsion. It is also important for environmental pollution and compliance with regulatory restrictions. The proposed activity will provide a high quality database, including well characterized boundary conditions. This will be made available on the web to the combustion community for further modeling within the framework of ongoing international collaborations, such as the Sandia-sponsored Turbulent Nonpremixed Flames Workshop.

The proposed research will be accompanied with teaching and outreach activities. The PI at Yale has advised female students, award winning graduate students and high school students. He has also trained local schoolteachers in the development of K-12 curricular units focused on energy.  He will continue to pursue these activities and integrate them with the project. The Cornell PI has a good track record of recruiting women Ph.D. students and transferring the fruits of his research to industry. Undergraduate students will be exposed to experimentally simple projects, such as flow visualization and phenomenological evidence of various burning regimes.

por.por_cntn:
This research project combined experiments and computational modeling to advance our understanding of turbulent combustion and our modeling capabilities through a collaboration between Yale University and Cornell University. The specific aim is to study a combustion configuration, the turbulent counterflow flame (TCF), that presents distinct advantages with respect to more conventional configurations such as jet flames that have been extensively used to date. The major objective of using TCFs for fundamental studies is to have a well-controlled laboratory system that can mimic the behavior of practical flames, is well suited to optical diagnostics and can be modeled conveniently. The experimental focus was on premixed flames. Intense strain, turbulence, heat transfer, and mixing with combustion products can affect premixed flames in practical combustion devices. These effects were systematically studied in turbulent premixed methane flames using a reactant -versus- product counterflow system and independently varying bulk strain rate, turbulent Reynolds number, equivalence ratio of the reactant mixture, temperature and equivalence ration of the counterflowing combustion products. Specifically, we investigated the impact of these variables on local flame extinction, ignitability and stability in the counterflow burner geometry. Flame stability and probability of local extinctions were rationalized in terms of the ignitibility of the lean-to-rich reactant mixtures by the hot products and how the varied parameters change the separation of the turbulent brush with respect to the counterflowing combustion products. The simulations predict the experimentally-observed trends of the effects of these critical parameters on the turbulent premixed flame very well. Furthermore, the comparison of simulation results with the experimental data showed good match also for non-reactive and non-premixed reactive simulations.

Turbulent combustion remains a major technical challenge that affects the behavior of the vast majority of systems relying on combustion for power generation or propulsion. Worldwide, it affects an industry of hundreds of billions of dollars, which will rely on fossil fuels for several decades to come, despite optimistic claims on the advent of clean renewable energy. With public opinion concern for the environmental impact of combustion devices, compliance with regulatory restrictions and minimization of fuel consumption impose a quantitative understanding of turbulent combustion. Results of this project were disseminated at technical meetings and in peer-reviewed articles. Furthermore, data sets were made available not only to our partners at Cornell but also to several groups, who initiated modeling of the experimental flames. The grant partially supported a mix of postdocs and (visiting) graduate students.
